Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 8: What is a common side effect of chemotherapy? Options: A. Hair growth, B. Increased fertility, C. Hair loss, D. Increased appetite**

Although the question is not an exact match, the content and intent of the question are related to the disadvantage of chemotherapy mentioned in the ground truth MCQ. The correct option in the ground truth MCQ states that chemotherapy "affects other healthy cells in the body," which can lead to side effects such as hair loss.

However, a closer match is not available among the generated MCQs. If I had to choose an index, I would choose **8**, but I would like to note that a more similar question would be one that asks about the disadvantage of chemotherapy, such as "What is a major disadvantage of chemotherapy?" with options that include "It affects other healthy cells in the body."

If I were to create a new question that matches the ground truth MCQ more closely, I would suggest:

**Question: What is a major disadvantage of chemotherapy? Options: A. It only targets cancer cells, B. It has no side effects, C. It affects other healthy cells in the body, D. It is only used for slow-growing cancers**

This new question matches the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ more closely.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
During World War I, one of the 
horrors of trench warfare was a poisonous yellow cloud 
called mustard gas. For those unlucky enough to be exposed, it made the air impossible to breathe, 
burned their eyes, and caused huge blisters on exposed skin. Scientists tried desperately to develop an
antidote to this vicious weapon of war. In the process they discovered the gas 
was irrevocably damaging the bone marrow of affected soldiers— halting its 
ability to make blood cells. Despite these awful effects, 
it gave scientists an idea. Cancer cells share a characteristic with 
bone marrow: both replicate rapidly. So could one of the atrocities of war become a champion in the 
fight against cancer? Researchers in the 1930s 
investigated this idea by injecting compounds derived 
from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients. It took time and trial and error to find 
treatments that did more good than harm, but by the end of World War II, they discovered what became known 
as the first chemotherapy drugs. Today, there are more than 100. Chemotherapy drugs are delivered 
through pills and injections and use "cytotoxic agents," which means 
compounds that are toxic to living cells. Essentially, these medicines cause some 
level of harm to all cells in the body— even healthy ones. But they reserve their most powerful 
effects for rapidly-dividing cells, which is precisely the hallmark of cancer. Take, for example, those first 
chemotherapy drugs, which are still used today and 
are called alkylating agents. They’re injected into the bloodstream, which delivers them to 
cells all over the body. Once inside, when the cell exposes 
its DNA in order to copy it, they damage the building blocks of 
DNA’s double helix structure, which can lead to cell death unless 
the damage is repaired. Because cancer cells multiply rapidly, they take in a high concentration 
of alkylating agents, and their DNA is frequently exposed 
and rarely repaired. So they die off more often 
than most other cells, which have time to fix damaged DNA and don’t accumulate the same 
concentrations of alkylating agents. Another form of chemotherapy involves 
compounds called microtubule stabilizers. Cells have small tubes that assemble 
to help with cell division and DNA replication, then break back down. When microtubule stabilizers 
get inside a cell, they keep those tiny tubes 
from disassembling. That prevents the cell from completing 
its replication, leading to its death. These are just two examples of the six 
classes of chemotherapy drugs we use to treat cancer today. But despite its huge benefits, 
chemotherapy has one big disadvantage: it affects other healthy cells in the body
that naturally have to renew rapidly. Hair follicles, the cells of the mouth, 
the gastrointestinal lining, the reproductive system, and bone marrow 
are hit nearly as hard as cancer. Similar to cancer cells, the rapid 
production of these normal cells means that they’re reaching for 
resources more frequently— and are therefore more exposed to 
the effects of chemo drugs. That leads to several common side 
effects of chemotherapy, including hair loss, fatigue, infertility,
nausea, and vomiting. Doctors commonly prescribe options 
to help manage these side-effects, such as strong anti-nausea medications. For hair loss, devices called cold caps 
can help lower the temperature around the head and 
constrict blood vessels, limiting the amount of chemotherapy 
drugs that reach hair follicles. And once a course of chemo 
treatment is over, the healthy tissues that’ve been badly 
affected by the drug will recover and begin to renew as usual. In 2018 alone, over 17 million people 
world-wide received a cancer diagnosis. But chemotherapy and other treatments 
have changed the outlook for so many. Just take the fact that up to 95% of 
individuals with testicular cancer survive it, thanks to advances 
in treatment. Even in people with acute myeloid 
leukemia— an aggressive blood cancer— chemotherapy puts an estimated 
60% of patients under 60 into remission following their 
first phase of treatment. Researchers are still developing 
more precise interventions that only target the intended 
cancer cells. That’ll help improve survival rates 
while leaving healthy tissues with reduced harm, making one of the best tools we have 
in the fight against cancer even better.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cells have small tubes that assemble and disassemble to help with cell division and DNA replication. Microtubule Stabilizers work by ___________.
Options: A. Preventing those tubes from disassembling., B. Preventing those tubes from assembling., C. Disallowing growth of those tubes., D. Damaging the building blocks of DNA’s double helix structure.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the poisonous yellow cloud that affected soldiers during World War I? Options: A. Mustard gas, B. Chlorine gas, C. Phosgene gas, D. Cyanide gas Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the effect of mustard gas on the bone marrow of affected soldiers? Options: A. It increased the production of blood cells, B. It had no effect on the bone marrow, C. It halted the ability to make blood cells, D. It reduced the production of white blood cells Correct Option: None
Question 3: What characteristic do cancer cells share with bone marrow? Options: A. They both produce hormones, B. They both replicate rapidly, C. They both produce antibodies, D. They both regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 4: What were the first chemotherapy drugs derived from? Options: A. Mustard gas, B. Penicillin, C. Aspirin, D. Morphine Correct Option: None
Question 5: How do chemotherapy drugs affect rapidly-dividing cells? Options: A. They have no effect on rapidly-dividing cells, B. They slow down the division of rapidly-dividing cells, C. They reserve their most powerful effects for rapidly-dividing cells, D. They increase the division of rapidly-dividing cells Correct Option: None
Question 6: What type of compounds are used in chemotherapy to damage the DNA of cancer cells? Options: A. Alkylating agents, B. Microtubule stabilizers, C. Hormone blockers, D. Antibiotics Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the effect of microtubule stabilizers on cell division? Options: A. They promote cell division, B. They slow down cell division, C. They prevent the cell from completing its replication, D. They have no effect on cell division Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is a common side effect of chemotherapy? Options: A. Hair growth, B. Increased fertility, C. Hair loss, D. Increased appetite Correct Option: None
Question 9: How can doctors help manage the side effects of chemotherapy? Options: A. By prescribing strong anti-nausea medications, B. By using cold caps to limit hair loss, C. By prescribing antibiotics, D. Both A and B Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the estimated remission rate for patients with acute myeloid leukemia under 60 following their first phase of chemotherapy treatment? Options: A. 20%, B. 40%, C. 60%, D. 80% Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7: What is the effect of microtubule stabilizers on cell division? Options: A. They promote cell division, B. They slow down cell division, C. They prevent the cell from completing its replication, D. They have no effect on cell division.

This question is similar in intent and content to the ground truth MCQ, which asks how microtubule stabilizers work. The correct option in Question 7 (C. They prevent the cell from completing its replication) is equivalent to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (A. Preventing those tubes from disassembling), as both describe the mechanism by which microtubule stabilizers inhibit cell division.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
During World War I, one of the 
horrors of trench warfare was a poisonous yellow cloud 
called mustard gas. For those unlucky enough to be exposed, it made the air impossible to breathe, 
burned their eyes, and caused huge blisters on exposed skin. Scientists tried desperately to develop an
antidote to this vicious weapon of war. In the process they discovered the gas 
was irrevocably damaging the bone marrow of affected soldiers— halting its 
ability to make blood cells. Despite these awful effects, 
it gave scientists an idea. Cancer cells share a characteristic with 
bone marrow: both replicate rapidly. So could one of the atrocities of war become a champion in the 
fight against cancer? Researchers in the 1930s 
investigated this idea by injecting compounds derived 
from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients. It took time and trial and error to find 
treatments that did more good than harm, but by the end of World War II, they discovered what became known 
as the first chemotherapy drugs. Today, there are more than 100. Chemotherapy drugs are delivered 
through pills and injections and use "cytotoxic agents," which means 
compounds that are toxic to living cells. Essentially, these medicines cause some 
level of harm to all cells in the body— even healthy ones. But they reserve their most powerful 
effects for rapidly-dividing cells, which is precisely the hallmark of cancer. Take, for example, those first

are called alkylating agents. They’re injected into the bloodstream, which delivers them to 
cells all over the body. Once inside, when the cell exposes 
its DNA in order to copy it, they damage the building blocks of

the damage is repaired. Because cancer cells multiply rapidly, they take in a high concentration 
of alkylating agents, and their DNA is frequently exposed 
and rarely repaired. So they die off more often 
than most other cells, which have time to fix damaged DNA and don’t accumulate the same

to help with cell division and DNA replication, then break back down. When microtubule stabilizers 
get inside a cell, they keep those tiny tubes 
from disassembling. That prevents the cell from completing 
its replication, leading to its death. These are just two examples of the six 
classes of chemotherapy drugs we use to treat cancer today. But despite its huge benefits,

that naturally have to renew rapidly. Hair follicles, the cells of the mouth, 
the gastrointestinal lining, the reproductive system, and bone marrow 
are hit nearly as hard as cancer. Similar to cancer cells, the rapid 
production of these normal cells means that they’re reaching for 
resources more frequently— and are therefore more exposed to 
the effects of chemo drugs. That leads to several common side 
effects of chemotherapy, including hair loss, fatigue, infertility,
nausea, and vomiting. Doctors commonly prescribe options 
to help manage these side-effects, such as strong anti-nausea medications. For hair loss, devices called cold caps 
can help lower the temperature around the head and 
constrict blood vessels, limiting the amount of chemotherapy 
drugs that reach hair follicles. And once a course of chemo 
treatment is over, the healthy tissues that’ve been badly 
affected by the drug will recover and begin to renew as usual. In 2018 alone, over 17 million people 
world-wide received a cancer diagnosis. But chemotherapy and other treatments 
have changed the outlook for so many. Just take the fact that up to 95% of 
individuals with testicular cancer survive it, thanks to advances 
in treatment. Even in people with acute myeloid

60% of patients under 60 into remission following their 
first phase of treatment. Researchers are still developing 
more precise interventions that only target the intended 
cancer cells. That’ll help improve survival rates 
while leaving healthy tissues with reduced harm, making one of the best tools we have 
in the fight against cancer even better.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Chemotherapy strongly affects cells in the body that naturally have to renew rapidly, such as __________.
Options: A. Hair follicles., B. Bone marrow., C. The gastrointestinal lining., D. All of the above.
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1970, marijuana was classified 
as a schedule 1 drug in the United States: the strictest designation possible, meaning it was completely illegal 
and had no recognized medical uses. For decades, this view persisted and set back research 
on the drug's mechanisms and effects. Today, marijuana’s therapeutic benefits 
are widely acknowledged, and some nations 
have legalized medical use or are moving in that direction. But a growing recognition 
for marijuana’s medical value doesn’t answer the question: is recreational marijuana use 
bad for your brain? Marijuana acts 
on the body’s cannabinoid system, which has receptors 
all over the brain and body. Molecules native to the body, 
called endocannabinoids, also act on these receptors. We don’t totally understand 
the cannabinoid system, but it has one feature 
that provides a big clue to its function. Most neurotransmitters 
travel from one neuron to the next through a synapse to propagate a message. But endocannabinoids 
travel in the opposite direction. When a message passes 
from the one neuron to the next, the receiving neuron 
releases endocannabinoids. Those endocannabinoids 
travel backward to influence the sending neuron— essentially giving it feedback 
from the receiving neuron. This leads scientists 
to believe that the endocannabinoid system serves primarily 
to modulate other kinds of signals— amplifying some and diminishing others. Feedback from endocannabinoids 
slows down rates of neural signaling. That doesn’t necessarily mean it slows down behavior 
or perception, though. For example, 
slowing down a signal that inhibits smell could actually make smells more intense. Marijuana contains 
two main active compounds, tetrahydrocannabinol or THC, 
and cannabidiol, or CBD. THC is thought to be primarily responsible
for marijuana’s psychoactive effects on behavior, cognition, and perception, while CBD is responsible 
for the non-psychoactive effects. Like endocannabinoids, THC slows down signaling 
by binding to cannabinoid receptors. But it binds to receptors 
all over this sprawling, diffuse system at once, whereas endocannabinoids 
are released in a specific place in response to a specific stimulus. This widespread activity 
coupled with the fact that the cannabinoid system
indirectly affects many other systems, means that each person’s 
particular brain chemistry, genetics, and previous life experience largely determine 
how they experience the drug. That’s true much more so with marijuana 
than with other drugs that produce their effects 
through one or a few specific pathways. So the harmful effects, if any, 
vary considerably from person to person. And while we don’t know 
how exactly how marijuana produces specific harmful effects, there are clear risk factors 
that can increase peoples’ likelihood of experiencing them. The clearest risk factor is age. In people younger than 25, cannabinoid receptors 
are more concentrated in the white matter than in people over 25. The white matter 
is involved in communication, learning, memory, and emotions. Frequent marijuana use can disrupt the development 
of white matter tracts, and also affect the brain’s ability 
to grow new connections. This may damage long-term learning ability
and problem solving. For now, it’s unclear 
how severe this damage can be or whether it’s reversible. And even among young people, the risk is higher the younger someone is— much higher for a 15 year old 
than a 22 year old, for instance. Marijuana can also cause hallucinations 
or paranoid delusions. Known as marijuana-induced psychosis, these symptoms usually subside 
when a person stops using marijuana. But in rare cases, 
psychosis doesn’t subside, instead unmasking 
a persistent psychotic disorder. A family history of psychotic disorders, 
like schizophrenia, is the clearest, though not the only, 
risk factor for this effect. Marijuana-induced psychosis 
is also more common among young adults, though it’s worth noting 
that psychotic disorders usually surface in this age range anyway. What’s unclear in these cases 
is whether the psychotic disorder would have appeared 
without marijuana use— whether marijuana use triggers it early, is a catalyst for a tipping point 
that wouldn’t have been crossed otherwise, or whether the reaction 
to marijuana is merely an indication of an underlying disorder. In all likelihood, marijuana’s role 
varies from person to person. At any age, as with many other drugs, the brain and body become less sensitive 
to marijuana after repeated uses, meaning it takes more 
to achieve the same effects. Fortunately, unlike many other drugs, there’s no risk of fatal overdose 
from marijuana, and even heavy use 
doesn’t lead to debilitating or life-threatening 
withdrawal symptoms if use stops. There are more subtle forms 
of marijuana withdrawal, though, including sleep disturbances, 
irritability, and depressed mood, which pass 
within a few weeks of stopping use. So is marijuana bad for your brain? It depends who you are. But while some risk factors 
are easy to identify, others aren’t well understood— which means there’s still some possibility
of experiencing negative effects, even if you don’t have 
any of the known risk factors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following are active compounds in marijuana?
Options: A. THC, B. CBD, C. THC and CBD, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year was marijuana classified as a schedule 1 drug in the United States? Options: A. 1960, B. 1970, C. 1980, D. 1990 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary function of the endocannabinoid system in the human body? Options: A. To transmit signals from one neuron to the next, B. To modulate other kinds of signals by amplifying some and diminishing others, C. To produce psychoactive effects on behavior, cognition, and perception, D. To regulate the immune system Correct Option: None
Question 3: Which compound in marijuana is thought to be primarily responsible for its psychoactive effects? Options: A. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), B. Cannabidiol (CBD), C. Endocannabinoids, D. Cannabinoid receptors Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the clearest risk factor for experiencing harmful effects from marijuana use? Options: A. Family history of psychotic disorders, B. Age, C. Previous life experience, D. Genetics Correct Option: None
Question 5: How does frequent marijuana use affect the brain's white matter tracts in people younger than 25? Options: A. It enhances their development, B. It has no effect on their development, C. It disrupts their development, D. It accelerates their growth Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is marijuana-induced psychosis, and what are its symptoms? Options: A. A type of cancer caused by marijuana use, characterized by hallucinations and paranoid delusions, B. A type of mental disorder caused by marijuana use, characterized by hallucinations and paranoid delusions, C. A type of physical disorder caused by marijuana use, characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, D. A type of emotional disorder caused by marijuana use, characterized by anxiety and depression Correct Option: None
Question 7: What happens to the brain and body after repeated uses of marijuana? Options: A. They become more sensitive to the drug, B. They become less sensitive to the drug, C. They remain unchanged, D. They experience withdrawal symptoms Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is a potential risk of marijuana use, especially among young adults? Options: A. Fatal overdose, B. Debilitating or life-threatening withdrawal symptoms, C. Persistent psychotic disorder, D. Increased heart rate Correct Option: None
Question 9: What are some subtle forms of marijuana withdrawal? Options: A. Sleep disturbances, irritability, and depressed mood, B. Hallucinations, paranoid delusions, and anxiety, C. Muscle weakness, fatigue, and headaches, D. Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea Correct Option: None
Question 10: According to the transcript, is marijuana bad for your brain? Options: A. Yes, it is bad for everyone's brain, B. No, it is not bad for anyone's brain, C. It depends on who you are and your individual risk factors, D. There is not enough research to determine its effects on the brain Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is not explicitly listed. However, based on the content and intent, I can suggest that a combination of Question 3 and another question about CBD could match the ground truth MCQ.

Since this is not an option, I will provide the index of the generated MCQ that partially matches the ground truth MCQ:

 Question 3: Which compound in marijuana is thought to be primarily responsible for its psychoactive effects? 

This question is related to the active compounds in marijuana, but it only asks about the compound responsible for psychoactive effects, which is THC. The ground truth MCQ asks about both THC and CBD as active compounds in marijuana.

If I had to choose an index, I would say: 3

However, please note that this is not an exact match, and a more accurate generated MCQ would be one that asks about both THC and CBD as active compounds in marijuana.

from marijuana, and even heavy use

any of the known risk factors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cannabinoid receptors are more concentrated in the while matter in people younger than:
Options: A. 18, B. 25, C. 14, D. 40
Correct Option: B

Question 1: In what year was marijuana classified as a schedule 1 drug in the United States? Options: A. 1960, B. 1970, C. 1980, D. 1990 Correct Option: None

A type of emotional disorder caused by marijuana use, characterized by anxiety and depression Correct Option: None

It depends on who you are and your individual risk factors, D. There is not enough research to determine its effects on the brain Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1970, marijuana was classified 
as a schedule 1 drug in the United States: the strictest designation possible, meaning it was completely illegal 
and had no recognized medical uses. For decades, this view persisted and set back research 
on the drug's mechanisms and effects. Today, marijuana’s therapeutic benefits 
are widely acknowledged, and some nations 
have legalized medical use or are moving in that direction. But a growing recognition 
for marijuana’s medical value doesn’t answer the question: is recreational marijuana use 
bad for your brain? Marijuana acts 
on the body’s cannabinoid system, which has receptors 
all over the brain and body. Molecules native to the body, 
called endocannabinoids, also act on these receptors. We don’t totally understand 
the cannabinoid system, but it has one feature 
that provides a big clue to its function. Most neurotransmitters 
travel from one neuron to the next through a synapse to propagate a message. But endocannabinoids 
travel in the opposite direction. When a message passes 
from the one neuron to the next, the receiving neuron 
releases endocannabinoids. Those endocannabinoids 
travel backward to influence the sending neuron— essentially giving it feedback 
from the receiving neuron. This leads scientists 
to believe that the endocannabinoid system serves primarily 
to modulate other kinds of signals— amplifying some and diminishing others. Feedback from endocannabinoids 
slows down rates of neural signaling. That doesn’t necessarily mean it slows down behavior 
or perception, though. For example, 
slowing down a signal that inhibits smell could actually make smells more intense. Marijuana contains 
two main active compounds, tetrahydrocannabinol or THC, 
and cannabidiol, or CBD. THC is thought to be primarily responsible
for marijuana’s psychoactive effects on behavior, cognition, and perception, while CBD is responsible 
for the non-psychoactive effects. Like endocannabinoids, THC slows down signaling 
by binding to cannabinoid receptors. But it binds to receptors 
all over this sprawling, diffuse system at once, whereas endocannabinoids 
are released in a specific place in response to a specific stimulus. This widespread activity 
coupled with the fact that the cannabinoid system
indirectly affects many other systems, means that each person’s 
particular brain chemistry, genetics, and previous life experience largely determine 
how they experience the drug. That’s true much more so with marijuana 
than with other drugs that produce their effects 
through one or a few specific pathways. So the harmful effects, if any, 
vary considerably from person to person. And while we don’t know 
how exactly how marijuana produces specific harmful effects, there are clear risk factors 
that can increase peoples’ likelihood of experiencing them. The clearest risk factor is age. In people younger than 25, cannabinoid receptors 
are more concentrated in the white matter than in people over 25. The white matter 
is involved in communication, learning, memory, and emotions. Frequent marijuana use can disrupt the development 
of white matter tracts, and also affect the brain’s ability 
to grow new connections. This may damage long-term learning ability
and problem solving. For now, it’s unclear 
how severe this damage can be or whether it’s reversible. And even among young people, the risk is higher the younger someone is— much higher for a 15 year old 
than a 22 year old, for instance. Marijuana can also cause hallucinations 
or paranoid delusions. Known as marijuana-induced psychosis, these symptoms usually subside 
when a person stops using marijuana. But in rare cases, 
psychosis doesn’t subside, instead unmasking 
a persistent psychotic disorder. A family history of psychotic disorders, 
like schizophrenia, is the clearest, though not the only, 
risk factor for this effect. Marijuana-induced psychosis 
is also more common among young adults, though it’s worth noting 
that psychotic disorders usually surface in this age range anyway. What’s unclear in these cases 
is whether the psychotic disorder would have appeared 
without marijuana use— whether marijuana use triggers it early, is a catalyst for a tipping point 
that wouldn’t have been crossed otherwise, or whether the reaction 
to marijuana is merely an indication of an underlying disorder. In all likelihood, marijuana’s role 
varies from person to person. At any age, as with many other drugs, the brain and body become less sensitive 
to marijuana after repeated uses, meaning it takes more 
to achieve the same effects. Fortunately, unlike many other drugs, there’s no risk of fatal overdose 
from marijuana, and even heavy use 
doesn’t lead to debilitating or life-threatening 
withdrawal symptoms if use stops. There are more subtle forms 
of marijuana withdrawal, though, including sleep disturbances, 
irritability, and depressed mood, which pass 
within a few weeks of stopping use. So is marijuana bad for your brain? It depends who you are. But while some risk factors 
are easy to identify, others aren’t well understood— which means there’s still some possibility
of experiencing negative effects, even if you don’t have 
any of the known risk factors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or false: There is a risk of fatal overdose from marijuana use.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

To modulate other kinds of signals by amplifying some and diminishing others, C. To produce psychoactive effects on behavior, cognition, and perception, D. To regulate the immune system Correct Option: None

Question 5: How does frequent marijuana use affect the brain's white matter tracts in people younger than 25? Options: A. It enhances their development, B. It has no effect on their development, C. It disrupts their development, D. It accelerates their growth Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is marijuana-induced psychosis, and what are its symptoms? Options: A. A type of cancer caused by marijuana use, characterized by hallucinations and paranoid delusions, B. A type of mental disorder caused by marijuana use, characterized by hallucinations and paranoid delusions, C. A type of physical disorder caused by marijuana use, characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, D. Since this is not available, I will choose the closest match based on content.

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
In 1970, marijuana was classified 
as a schedule 1 drug in the United States: the strictest designation possible, meaning it was completely illegal 
and had no recognized medical uses. For decades, this view persisted and set back research 
on the drug's mechanisms and effects. Today, marijuana’s therapeutic benefits 
are widely acknowledged, and some nations 
have legalized medical use or are moving in that direction. But a growing recognition 
for marijuana’s medical value doesn’t answer the question: is recreational marijuana use 
bad for your brain? Marijuana acts 
on the body’s cannabinoid system, which has receptors 
all over the brain and body. Molecules native to the body, 
called endocannabinoids, also act on these receptors. We don’t totally understand 
the cannabinoid system, but it has one feature 
that provides a big clue to its function. Most neurotransmitters 
travel from one neuron to the next through a synapse to propagate a message. But endocannabinoids 
travel in the opposite direction. When a message passes 
from the one neuron to the next, the receiving neuron 
releases endocannabinoids. Those endocannabinoids 
travel backward to influence the sending neuron— essentially giving it feedback 
from the receiving neuron. This leads scientists 
to believe that the endocannabinoid system serves primarily 
to modulate other kinds of signals— amplifying some and diminishing others. Feedback from endocannabinoids 
slows down rates of neural signaling. That doesn’t necessarily mean it slows down behavior 
or perception, though. For example, 
slowing down a signal that inhibits smell could actually make smells more intense. Marijuana contains 
two main active compounds, tetrahydrocannabinol or THC, 
and cannabidiol, or CBD. THC is thought to be primarily responsible
for marijuana’s psychoactive effects on behavior, cognition, and perception, while CBD is responsible 
for the non-psychoactive effects. Like endocannabinoids, THC slows down signaling 
by binding to cannabinoid receptors. But it binds to receptors 
all over this sprawling, diffuse system at once, whereas endocannabinoids 
are released in a specific place in response to a specific stimulus. This widespread activity 
coupled with the fact that the cannabinoid system
indirectly affects many other systems, means that each person’s 
particular brain chemistry, genetics, and previous life experience largely determine 
how they experience the drug. That’s true much more so with marijuana 
than with other drugs that produce their effects 
through one or a few specific pathways. So the harmful effects, if any, 
vary considerably from person to person. And while we don’t know 
how exactly how marijuana produces specific harmful effects, there are clear risk factors 
that can increase peoples’ likelihood of experiencing them. The clearest risk factor is age. In people younger than 25, cannabinoid receptors 
are more concentrated in the white matter than in people over 25. The white matter 
is involved in communication, learning, memory, and emotions. Frequent marijuana use can disrupt the development 
of white matter tracts, and also affect the brain’s ability 
to grow new connections. This may damage long-term learning ability
and problem solving. For now, it’s unclear 
how severe this damage can be or whether it’s reversible. And even among young people, the risk is higher the younger someone is— much higher for a 15 year old 
than a 22 year old, for instance. Marijuana can also cause hallucinations 
or paranoid delusions. Known as marijuana-induced psychosis, these symptoms usually subside 
when a person stops using marijuana. But in rare cases, 
psychosis doesn’t subside, instead unmasking 
a persistent psychotic disorder. A family history of psychotic disorders, 
like schizophrenia, is the clearest, though not the only, 
risk factor for this effect. Marijuana-induced psychosis 
is also more common among young adults, though it’s worth noting 
that psychotic disorders usually surface in this age range anyway. What’s unclear in these cases 
is whether the psychotic disorder would have appeared 
without marijuana use— whether marijuana use triggers it early, is a catalyst for a tipping point 
that wouldn’t have been crossed otherwise, or whether the reaction 
to marijuana is merely an indication of an underlying disorder. In all likelihood, marijuana’s role 
varies from person to person. At any age, as with many other drugs, the brain and body become less sensitive 
to marijuana after repeated uses, meaning it takes more 
to achieve the same effects. Fortunately, unlike many other drugs, there’s no risk of fatal overdose 
from marijuana, and even heavy use 
doesn’t lead to debilitating or life-threatening 
withdrawal symptoms if use stops. There are more subtle forms 
of marijuana withdrawal, though, including sleep disturbances, 
irritability, and depressed mood, which pass 
within a few weeks of stopping use. So is marijuana bad for your brain? It depends who you are. But while some risk factors 
are easy to identify, others aren’t well understood— which means there’s still some possibility
of experiencing negative effects, even if you don’t have 
any of the known risk factors.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Meet Lucy. She was a math major in college, and aced all her courses in probability 
and statistics. Which do you think is more likely: that 
Lucy is a portrait artist, or that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker? In studies of similar questions, up to 80 
percent of participants chose the equivalent 
of the second statement: that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker. After all, nothing we know about Lucy 
suggests an affinity for art, but statistics and probability 
are useful in poker. And yet, this is the wrong answer. Look at the options again. How do we know the first statement 
is more likely to be true? Because it’s a less specific version 
of the second statement. Saying that Lucy is a portrait artist 
doesn’t make any claims about what else she might or might not do. But even though it’s far easier to imagine
her playing poker than making art based on the background information, the second statement is only true if she 
does both of these things. However counterintuitive it seems 
to imagine Lucy as an artist, the second scenario adds another condition
on top of that, making it less likely. For any possible set of events, the 
likelihood of A occurring will always be greater than the likelihood
of A and B both occurring. If we took a random sample of a million 
people who majored in math, the subset who are portrait artists might 
be relatively small. But it will necessarily be bigger than the subset who are portrait artists 
and play poker. Anyone who belongs to the second group 
will also belong to the first– but not vice versa. The more conditions there are, 
the less likely an event becomes. So why do statements with more conditions
sometimes seem more believable? This is a phenomenon known as 
the conjunction fallacy. When we’re asked to make quick decisions, 
we tend to look for shortcuts. In this case, we look for what seems 
plausible rather than what is statistically 
most probable. On its own, Lucy being an artist doesn’t 
match the expectations formed by the preceding information. The additional detail about 
her playing poker gives us a narrative that resonates 
with our intuitions— it makes it seem more plausible. And we choose the option that seems more
representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability. This effect has been observed 
across multiple studies, including ones with participants 
who understood statistics well– from students betting on 
sequences of dice rolls, to foreign policy experts predicting 
the likelihood of a diplomatic crisis. The conjunction fallacy isn’t just a 
problem in hypothetical situations. Conspiracy theories and false news stories often rely on a version of the conjunction
fallacy to seem credible– the more resonant details are added 
to an outlandish story, the more plausible it begins to seem. But ultimately, the likelihood 
a story is true can never be greater than the probability 
that its least likely component is true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these sequences of coin flips would you be most likely to bet on?
Options: A. THTHHH, B. THTHHHT, C. HTHHH
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Lucy's major in college? Options: A. Statistics, B. Math, C. Art, D. Psychology Correct Option: None
Question 2: In studies, what percentage of participants chose the equivalent of the statement "Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker"? Options: A. 20%, B. 50%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why is the statement "Lucy is a portrait artist" more likely to be true than "Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker"? Options: A. Because Lucy has an affinity for art, B. Because the first statement is a less specific version of the second statement, C. Because Lucy is more likely to play poker, D. Because Lucy majored in math Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the phenomenon known as the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. When we tend to look for what seems plausible rather than what is statistically most probable, B. When we choose the option that seems more representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability, C. When we ignore the least likely component of a story, D. When we add more conditions to an event to make it more likely Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the likelihood of an event when more conditions are added? Options: A. It becomes more likely, B. It becomes less likely, C. It remains the same, D. It becomes uncertain Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why do statements with more conditions sometimes seem more believable? Options: A. Because they are statistically more probable, B. Because they provide a narrative that resonates with our intuitions, C. Because they are less specific, D. Because they are more representative of the overall picture Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who is more likely to fall victim to the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. Only those who are unfamiliar with statistics, B. Only those who are familiar with statistics, C. Anyone, regardless of their understanding of statistics, D. Only experts in a particular field Correct Option: None
Question 8: What type of stories often rely on a version of the conjunction fallacy to seem credible? Options: A. News stories, B. Conspiracy theories and false news stories, C. Historical accounts, D. Scientific explanations Correct Option: None
Question 9: What determines the likelihood that a story is true? Options: A. The number of resonant details added to the story, B. The probability that its least likely component is true, C. The number of people who believe the story, D. The plausibility of the story Correct Option: None
Question 10: What happens when we choose an option based on the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. We choose the most statistically probable option, B. We choose the option that seems most plausible, C. We choose the option that is most representative of the overall picture, D. We choose the option that is least likely to be true Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Meet Lucy. She was a math major in college, and aced all her courses in probability 
and statistics. Which do you think is more likely: that 
Lucy is a portrait artist, or that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker? In studies of similar questions, up to 80 
percent of participants chose the equivalent 
of the second statement: that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker. After all, nothing we know about Lucy 
suggests an affinity for art, but statistics and probability 
are useful in poker. And yet, this is the wrong answer. Look at the options again. How do we know the first statement 
is more likely to be true? Because it’s a less specific version 
of the second statement. Saying that Lucy is a portrait artist 
doesn’t make any claims about what else she might or might not do. But even though it’s far easier to imagine
her playing poker than making art based on the background information, the second statement is only true if she 
does both of these things. However counterintuitive it seems 
to imagine Lucy as an artist, the second scenario adds another condition
on top of that, making it less likely. For any possible set of events, the 
likelihood of A occurring will always be greater than the likelihood
of A and B both occurring. If we took a random sample of a million 
people who majored in math, the subset who are portrait artists might 
be relatively small. But it will necessarily be bigger than the subset who are portrait artists 
and play poker. Anyone who belongs to the second group 
will also belong to the first– but not vice versa. The more conditions there are, 
the less likely an event becomes. So why do statements with more conditions
sometimes seem more believable? This is a phenomenon known as 
the conjunction fallacy. When we’re asked to make quick decisions, 
we tend to look for shortcuts. In this case, we look for what seems 
plausible rather than what is statistically 
most probable. On its own, Lucy being an artist doesn’t 
match the expectations formed by the preceding information. The additional detail about 
her playing poker gives us a narrative that resonates 
with our intuitions— it makes it seem more plausible. And we choose the option that seems more
representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability. This effect has been observed 
across multiple studies, including ones with participants 
who understood statistics well– from students betting on 
sequences of dice rolls, to foreign policy experts predicting 
the likelihood of a diplomatic crisis. The conjunction fallacy isn’t just a 
problem in hypothetical situations. Conspiracy theories and false news stories often rely on a version of the conjunction
fallacy to seem credible– the more resonant details are added 
to an outlandish story, the more plausible it begins to seem. But ultimately, the likelihood 
a story is true can never be greater than the probability 
that its least likely component is true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these events is most likely to occur?
Options: A. The United States declares war on Iran in response to an attack on an oil tanker, B. The United States declares war on Iran, C. The United States and the United Kingdom declare war on Iran
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was Lucy's major in college? Options: A. Statistics, B. Math, C. Art, D. Psychology Correct Option: None
Question 2: In studies, what percentage of participants chose the equivalent of the statement "Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker"? Options: A. 20%, B. 50%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: None
Question 3: Why is the statement "Lucy is a portrait artist" more likely to be true than "Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker"? Options: A. Because Lucy has an affinity for art, B. Because the first statement is a less specific version of the second statement, C. Because Lucy is more likely to play poker, D. Because Lucy majored in math Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the phenomenon known as the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. When we tend to look for what seems plausible rather than what is statistically most probable, B. When we choose the option that seems more representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability, C. When we ignore the least likely component of a story, D. When we add more conditions to an event to make it more likely Correct Option: None
Question 5: What happens to the likelihood of an event when more conditions are added? Options: A. It becomes more likely, B. It becomes less likely, C. It remains the same, D. It becomes uncertain Correct Option: None
Question 6: Why do statements with more conditions sometimes seem more believable? Options: A. Because they are statistically more probable, B. Because they provide a narrative that resonates with our intuitions, C. Because they are less specific, D. Because they are more representative of the overall picture Correct Option: None
Question 7: Who is more likely to fall victim to the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. Only those who are unfamiliar with statistics, B. Only those who are familiar with statistics, C. Anyone, regardless of their understanding of statistics, D. Only experts in a particular field Correct Option: None
Question 8: What type of stories often rely on a version of the conjunction fallacy to seem credible? Options: A. News stories, B. Conspiracy theories and false news stories, C. Historical accounts, D. Scientific explanations Correct Option: None
Question 9: What determines the likelihood that a story is true? Options: A. The number of resonant details added to the story, B. The probability that its least likely component is true, C. The number of people who believe the story, D. The plausibility of the story Correct Option: None
Question 10: What happens when we choose an option based on the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. We choose the most statistically probable option, B. We choose the option that seems most plausible, C. We choose the option that is most representative of the overall picture, D. We choose the option that is least likely to be true Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

Among the provided generated MCQs, none exactly match the ground truth MCQ. Nevertheless, if I had to choose the most similar one based on the concept of the conjunction fallacy and the idea of multiple conditions affecting the likelihood of an event, I would choose Question 5.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Meet Lucy. She was a math major in college, and aced all her courses in probability 
and statistics. Which do you think is more likely: that 
Lucy is a portrait artist, or that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker? In studies of similar questions, up to 80 
percent of participants chose the equivalent 
of the second statement: that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker. After all, nothing we know about Lucy 
suggests an affinity for art, but statistics and probability 
are useful in poker. And yet, this is the wrong answer. Look at the options again. How do we know the first statement 
is more likely to be true? Because it’s a less specific version 
of the second statement. Saying that Lucy is a portrait artist 
doesn’t make any claims about what else she might or might not do. But even though it’s far easier to imagine
her playing poker than making art based on the background information, the second statement is only true if she 
does both of these things. However counterintuitive it seems 
to imagine Lucy as an artist, the second scenario adds another condition
on top of that, making it less likely. For any possible set of events, the 
likelihood of A occurring will always be greater than the likelihood
of A and B both occurring. If we took a random sample of a million 
people who majored in math, the subset who are portrait artists might 
be relatively small. But it will necessarily be bigger than the subset who are portrait artists 
and play poker. Anyone who belongs to the second group 
will also belong to the first– but not vice versa. The more conditions there are, 
the less likely an event becomes. So why do statements with more conditions
sometimes seem more believable? This is a phenomenon known as 
the conjunction fallacy. When we’re asked to make quick decisions, 
we tend to look for shortcuts. In this case, we look for what seems 
plausible rather than what is statistically 
most probable. On its own, Lucy being an artist doesn’t 
match the expectations formed by the preceding information. The additional detail about 
her playing poker gives us a narrative that resonates 
with our intuitions— it makes it seem more plausible. And we choose the option that seems more
representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability. This effect has been observed 
across multiple studies, including ones with participants 
who understood statistics well– from students betting on 
sequences of dice rolls, to foreign policy experts predicting 
the likelihood of a diplomatic crisis. The conjunction fallacy isn’t just a 
problem in hypothetical situations. Conspiracy theories and false news stories often rely on a version of the conjunction
fallacy to seem credible– the more resonant details are added 
to an outlandish story, the more plausible it begins to seem. But ultimately, the likelihood 
a story is true can never be greater than the probability 
that its least likely component is true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following does NOT explain why we’re prone to the conjunction fallacy?
Options: A. Making snap judgments based on believability rather than calculation, B. Need to impose a narrative on a collection of details, C. Lack of knowledge about the particular subject
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1948, Spanish ophthalmologist 
Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner was fed up with glasses. He wanted a solution for blurry 
vision that fixed the eye itself, without relying on external aids. But the surgery he eventually devised 
was not for the faint of heart. Barraquer began by slicing off the front
of a patient’s cornea and dunking it in liquid nitrogen. Using a miniature lathe, he ground the 
frozen cornea into the precise shape necessary to focus
the patient’s vision. Then he thawed the disc, and sewed 
it back on. Barraquer called this procedure 
keratomileusis, from the Greek words for “carving” 
and “cornea.” And though it might sound grisly, 
his technique produced reliable results. So how did Barraquer’s surgery work? Keratomileusis corrects what are called 
refractive errors: imperfections in the way the eye focuses 
incoming light. Ideally, the cornea and lens work 
together to focus light on the surface of the retina, but several kinds of refractive errors 
can impair this delicate system. In people with myopia, 
or short-sightedness, a steep cornea focuses light just short 
of the retina. Those with hyperopia, or far-sightedness, 
have the opposite problem: light is focused too far 
beyond the retina. And in people with astigmatism, 
the cornea has two different curvatures which focus light at two distances and 
produce blurry vision. Even those with perfect vision will 
eventually suffer from presbyopia, or “aging eyes.” As the proteins in the lens age, they 
slowly increase its size. By an adult’s mid-40’s, the lens is too
large to easily change shape and shift focus. Glasses and contact lenses bend light 
to compensate for these refractive errors. But, as Barraquer’s procedure shows, we can also alter the shape 
of the cornea itself; moving the focal point backwards, 
forwards, or pulling a divided image together. And thankfully, modern eye surgeons can 
sculpt the cornea with far less invasive tools. In corrective laser eye surgery, surgeons 
rely on excimer lasers. These tools are accurate enough to etch 
words into a human hair. To safely accomplish these 
ultra-fine incisions, they use a technique called photoablation. This allows the laser to essentially 
evaporate organic tissue without overheating 
surrounding eye tissue. So how does laser eye surgery 
actually work? The first step is to separate a thin layer
from the front of the cornea. This can be done with either a flat, 
wide blade, or a femto-second laser that produces millions of tiny plasma 
bubbles to create a plane beneath 
the corneal surface. Surgeons then lift the flap to expose the 
inside of the cornea. Guided by the refractive error and the 
shape of the cornea, the excimer laser robotically sculpts the
exposed corneal bed into the correct shape. This process usually takes less than 30 
seconds for each eye. Finally, the flap is closed, and its edges reseal themselves 
in just a few hours. Because the lasering is done on 
the eyeball itself, it’s described as “in situ,” or “on site.” Its complete name is “laser in-situ 
keratomileusis” – but you probably know it as LASIK. Essentially, this technique carves a 
patient’s contact lens prescription onto their cornea. Like any surgical procedure, LASIK comes with certain risks. Some patients experience slightly blurred
vision that can’t be corrected by glasses. But the technique is currently about 
as likely to damage your eyes as wearing daily disposable contact 
lenses for one year. Today, a technique called SMILE enables 
surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions – further reducing recovery time. And lasers aren’t just correcting the 
three types of refractive errors – this technology can also 
restore aging eyes. In a technique called Laser 
Blended Vision, surgeons adjust one eye to be slightly 
better at distance vision and the other to be better 
at close range vision. The difference between the two eyes is 
small enough that most patients can merge their vision, allowing both eyes to work 
together at all distances. Advances in laser technology continue 
to make vision correction surgery more effective and accessible. One day soon, Barraquer’s vision of a 
world without glasses may finally come true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 5. In addition to far-sightedness and short-sightedness, LASIK can also treat which one of the following?
Options: A. Astigmatism, B. Age related decreased reading ability, C. Myopia, D. Hyperopia, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the Spanish ophthalmologist credited with devising the keratomileusis procedure in 1948? Options: A. Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner, B. Leonardo da Vinci, C. Sigmund Freud, D. Galen Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary goal of the keratomileusis procedure? Options: A. To strengthen eye muscles, B. To correct refractive errors by reshaping the cornea, C. To replace the lens with an artificial one, D. To improve eye color Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the term for the imperfections in the way the eye focuses incoming light? Options: A. Refractive errors, B. Corneal aberrations, C. Lens distortions, D. Retinal defects Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the condition where a steep cornea focuses light just short of the retina? Options: A. Hyperopia, B. Myopia, C. Astigmatism, D. Presbyopia Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the term for the aging of the lens, which affects its ability to change shape and focus? Options: A. Presbyopia, B. Myopia, C. Hyperopia, D. Astigmatism Correct Option: None
Question 6: What type of laser is used in corrective laser eye surgery to etch precise incisions? Options: A. Excimer laser, B. Femto-second laser, C. Argon laser, D. CO2 laser Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the technique used in laser eye surgery to evaporate organic tissue without overheating surrounding tissue? Options: A. Photoablation, B. Photocoagulation, C. Photorefractive keratectomy, D. Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the complete name of the surgical procedure that uses an excimer laser to sculpt the cornea? Options: A. Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK), B. Laser-assisted cataract surgery, C. Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK), D. Laser-induced keratomileusis Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the technique that enables surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions, reducing recovery time? Options: A. SMILE, B. LASIK, C. PRK, D. LASEK Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the technique that adjusts one eye for distance vision and the other for close range vision to restore aging eyes? Options: A. Laser Blended Vision, B. Monovision, C. Presbyopia correction, D. Refractive lens exchange Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent, the most similar generated MCQ is:

Question 3: What is the term for the imperfections in the way the eye focuses incoming light? Options: A. Refractive errors, B. Corneal aberrations, C. Lens distortions, D. Retinal defects

Although this question does not directly ask about the conditions treated by LASIK, it does relate to the concept of refractive errors, which is relevant to the ground truth MCQ. However, it's essential to note that the generated MCQs do not directly address the specific question asked in the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say Question 3 is the most similar, but I want to emphasize that it's not a direct match.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2

**Transcript**:
In 1948, Spanish ophthalmologist 
Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner was fed up with glasses. He wanted a solution for blurry 
vision that fixed the eye itself, without relying on external aids. But the surgery he eventually devised 
was not for the faint of heart. Barraquer began by slicing off the front
of a patient’s cornea and dunking it in liquid nitrogen. Using a miniature lathe, he ground the 
frozen cornea into the precise shape necessary to focus
the patient’s vision. Then he thawed the disc, and sewed 
it back on. Barraquer called this procedure 
keratomileusis, from the Greek words for “carving” 
and “cornea.” And though it might sound grisly, 
his technique produced reliable results. So how did Barraquer’s surgery work? Keratomileusis corrects what are called 
refractive errors: imperfections in the way the eye focuses 
incoming light. Ideally, the cornea and lens work 
together to focus light on the surface of the retina, but several kinds of refractive errors 
can impair this delicate system. In people with myopia, 
or short-sightedness, a steep cornea focuses light just short 
of the retina. Those with hyperopia, or far-sightedness, 
have the opposite problem: light is focused too far 
beyond the retina. And in people with astigmatism, 
the cornea has two different curvatures which focus light at two distances and 
produce blurry vision. Even those with perfect vision will 
eventually suffer from presbyopia, or “aging eyes.” As the proteins in the lens age, they 
slowly increase its size. By an adult’s mid-40’s, the lens is too
large to easily change shape and shift focus. Glasses and contact lenses bend light 
to compensate for these refractive errors. But, as Barraquer’s procedure shows, we can also alter the shape 
of the cornea itself; moving the focal point backwards, 
forwards, or pulling a divided image together. And thankfully, modern eye surgeons can 
sculpt the cornea with far less invasive tools. In corrective laser eye surgery, surgeons 
rely on excimer lasers. These tools are accurate enough to etch 
words into a human hair. To safely accomplish these 
ultra-fine incisions, they use a technique called photoablation. This allows the laser to essentially 
evaporate organic tissue without overheating 
surrounding eye tissue. So how does laser eye surgery 
actually work? The first step is to separate a thin layer
from the front of the cornea. This can be done with either a flat, 
wide blade, or a femto-second laser that produces millions of tiny plasma 
bubbles to create a plane beneath 
the corneal surface. Surgeons then lift the flap to expose the 
inside of the cornea. Guided by the refractive error and the 
shape of the cornea, the excimer laser robotically sculpts the
exposed corneal bed into the correct shape. This process usually takes less than 30 
seconds for each eye. Finally, the flap is closed, and its edges reseal themselves 
in just a few hours. Because the lasering is done on 
the eyeball itself, it’s described as “in situ,” or “on site.” Its complete name is “laser in-situ 
keratomileusis” – but you probably know it as LASIK. Essentially, this technique carves a 
patient’s contact lens prescription onto their cornea. Like any surgical procedure, LASIK comes with certain risks. Some patients experience slightly blurred
vision that can’t be corrected by glasses. But the technique is currently about 
as likely to damage your eyes as wearing daily disposable contact 
lenses for one year. Today, a technique called SMILE enables 
surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions – further reducing recovery time. And lasers aren’t just correcting the 
three types of refractive errors – this technology can also 
restore aging eyes. In a technique called Laser 
Blended Vision, surgeons adjust one eye to be slightly 
better at distance vision and the other to be better 
at close range vision. The difference between the two eyes is 
small enough that most patients can merge their vision, allowing both eyes to work 
together at all distances. Advances in laser technology continue 
to make vision correction surgery more effective and accessible. One day soon, Barraquer’s vision of a 
world without glasses may finally come true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In Myopia, the eye is focused at ________, is the medical term used for define which one of the following?
Options: A. Near, B. Far, C. Both near and far
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 3

**Transcript**:
In 1948, Spanish ophthalmologist 
Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner was fed up with glasses. He wanted a solution for blurry 
vision that fixed the eye itself, without relying on external aids. But the surgery he eventually devised 
was not for the faint of heart. Barraquer began by slicing off the front
of a patient’s cornea and dunking it in liquid nitrogen. Using a miniature lathe, he ground the 
frozen cornea into the precise shape necessary to focus
the patient’s vision. Then he thawed the disc, and sewed 
it back on. Barraquer called this procedure 
keratomileusis, from the Greek words for “carving” 
and “cornea.” And though it might sound grisly, 
his technique produced reliable results. So how did Barraquer’s surgery work? Keratomileusis corrects what are called 
refractive errors: imperfections in the way the eye focuses 
incoming light. Ideally, the cornea and lens work 
together to focus light on the surface of the retina, but several kinds of refractive errors 
can impair this delicate system. In people with myopia, 
or short-sightedness, a steep cornea focuses light just short 
of the retina. Those with hyperopia, or far-sightedness, 
have the opposite problem: light is focused too far 
beyond the retina. And in people with astigmatism, 
the cornea has two different curvatures which focus light at two distances and 
produce blurry vision. Even those with perfect vision will 
eventually suffer from presbyopia, or “aging eyes.” As the proteins in the lens age, they 
slowly increase its size. By an adult’s mid-40’s, the lens is too
large to easily change shape and shift focus. Glasses and contact lenses bend light 
to compensate for these refractive errors. But, as Barraquer’s procedure shows, we can also alter the shape 
of the cornea itself; moving the focal point backwards, 
forwards, or pulling a divided image together. And thankfully, modern eye surgeons can 
sculpt the cornea with far less invasive tools. In corrective laser eye surgery, surgeons 
rely on excimer lasers. These tools are accurate enough to etch 
words into a human hair. To safely accomplish these 
ultra-fine incisions, they use a technique called photoablation. This allows the laser to essentially 
evaporate organic tissue without overheating 
surrounding eye tissue. So how does laser eye surgery 
actually work? The first step is to separate a thin layer
from the front of the cornea. This can be done with either a flat, 
wide blade, or a femto-second laser that produces millions of tiny plasma 
bubbles to create a plane beneath 
the corneal surface. Surgeons then lift the flap to expose the

shape of the cornea, the excimer laser robotically sculpts the
exposed corneal bed into the correct shape. This process usually takes less than 30 
seconds for each eye. Finally, the flap is closed, and its edges reseal themselves 
in just a few hours. Because the lasering is done on 
the eyeball itself, it’s described as “in situ,” or “on site.” Its complete name is “laser in-situ

surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions – further reducing recovery time. And lasers aren’t just correcting the 
three types of refractive errors – this technology can also 
restore aging eyes. In a technique called Laser 
Blended Vision, surgeons adjust one eye to be slightly 
better at distance vision and the other to be better 
at close range vision. The difference between the two eyes is 
small enough that most patients can merge their vision, allowing both eyes to work 
together at all distances. Advances in laser technology continue 
to make vision correction surgery more effective and accessible. One day soon, Barraquer’s vision of a 
world without glasses may finally come true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Presbyopia, or aging eyes affecting the change in the ability of the eye to focus from distance to near, usually starts around what age?
Options: A. 25 years old, B. 45 years old, C. 65 years old
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner was fed up with glasses. He wanted a solution for blurry 
vision that fixed the eye itself, without relying on external aids. But the surgery he eventually devised 
was not for the faint of heart. Barraquer began by slicing off the front
of a patient’s cornea and dunking it in liquid nitrogen. Using a miniature lathe, he ground the 
frozen cornea into the precise shape necessary to focus
the patient’s vision. Then he thawed the disc, and sewed 
it back on. Barraquer called this procedure 
keratomileusis, from the Greek words for “carving” 
and “cornea.” And though it might sound grisly, 
his technique produced reliable results. So how did Barraquer’s surgery work? Keratomileusis corrects what are called 
refractive errors: imperfections in the way the eye focuses 
incoming light. Ideally, the cornea and lens work 
together to focus light on the surface of the retina, but several kinds of refractive errors 
can impair this delicate system. In people with myopia, 
or short-sightedness, a steep cornea focuses light just short 
of the retina. Those with hyperopia, or far-sightedness, 
have the opposite problem: light is focused too far 
beyond the retina. And in people with astigmatism, 
the cornea has two different curvatures which focus light at two distances and 
produce blurry vision. Even those with perfect vision will 
eventually suffer from presbyopia, or “aging eyes.” As the proteins in the lens age, they 
slowly increase its size. By an adult’s mid-40’s, the lens is too
large to easily change shape and shift focus. Glasses and contact lenses bend light 
to compensate for these refractive errors. But, as Barraquer’s procedure shows, we can also alter the shape 
of the cornea itself; moving the focal point backwards, 
forwards, or pulling a divided image together. And thankfully, modern eye surgeons can 
sculpt the cornea with far less invasive tools. In corrective laser eye surgery, surgeons 
rely on excimer lasers. These tools are accurate enough to etch 
words into a human hair. To safely accomplish these 
ultra-fine incisions, they use a technique called photoablation. This allows the laser to essentially 
evaporate organic tissue without overheating 
surrounding eye tissue. So how does laser eye surgery 
actually work? The first step is to separate a thin layer
from the front of the cornea. This can be done with either a flat, 
wide blade, or a femto-second laser that produces millions of tiny plasma 
bubbles to create a plane beneath 
the corneal surface. Surgeons then lift the flap to expose the 
inside of the cornea. Guided by the refractive error and the 
shape of the cornea, the excimer laser robotically sculpts the
exposed corneal bed into the correct shape. This process usually takes less than 30 
seconds for each eye. Finally, the flap is closed, and its edges reseal themselves 
in just a few hours. Because the lasering is done on 
the eyeball itself, it’s described as “in situ,” or “on site.” Its complete name is “laser in-situ 
keratomileusis” – but you probably know it as LASIK. Essentially, this technique carves a 
patient’s contact lens prescription onto their cornea. Like any surgical procedure, LASIK comes with certain risks. Some patients experience slightly blurred
vision that can’t be corrected by glasses. But the technique is currently about 
as likely to damage your eyes as wearing daily disposable contact 
lenses for one year. Today, a technique called SMILE enables 
surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions – further reducing recovery time. And lasers aren’t just correcting the 
three types of refractive errors – this technology can also 
restore aging eyes. In a technique called Laser 
Blended Vision, surgeons adjust one eye to be slightly 
better at distance vision and the other to be better 
at close range vision. The difference between the two eyes is 
small enough that most patients can merge their vision, allowing both eyes to work 
together at all distances. Advances in laser technology continue 
to make vision correction surgery more effective and accessible. One day soon, Barraquer’s vision of a 
world without glasses may finally come true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which one of the following best describes the safety of LASIK?
Options: A. LASIK is safer than contact lenses worn for more than 1 year, B. LASIK is not as safe as contact lenses, C. LASIK does not correct astigmatism
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is the Spanish ophthalmologist credited with devising the keratomileusis procedure in 1948? Options: A. Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner, B. Leonardo da Vinci, C. Sigmund Freud, D. Galen Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the primary goal of the keratomileusis procedure? Options: A. To strengthen eye muscles, B. To correct refractive errors by reshaping the cornea, C. To replace the lens with an artificial one, D. To improve eye color Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the term for the imperfections in the way the eye focuses incoming light? Options: A. Refractive errors, B. Corneal aberrations, C. Lens distortions, D. Retinal defects Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the condition where a steep cornea focuses light just short of the retina? Options: A. Hyperopia, B. Myopia, C. Astigmatism, D. Presbyopia Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the term for the aging of the lens, which affects its ability to change shape and focus? Options: A. Presbyopia, B. Myopia, C. Hyperopia, D. Astigmatism Correct Option: None
Question 6: What type of laser is used in corrective laser eye surgery to etch precise incisions? Options: A. Excimer laser, B. Femto-second laser, C. Argon laser, D. CO2 laser Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the technique used in laser eye surgery to evaporate organic tissue without overheating surrounding tissue? Options: A. Photoablation, B. Photocoagulation, C. Photorefractive keratectomy, D. Laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the complete name of the surgical procedure that uses an excimer laser to sculpt the cornea? Options: A. Laser in-situ keratomileusis (LASIK), B. Laser-assisted cataract surgery, C. Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK), D. Laser-induced keratomileusis Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the technique that enables surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions, reducing recovery time? Options: A. SMILE, B. LASIK, C. PRK, D. LASEK Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the technique that adjusts one eye for distance vision and the other for close range vision to restore aging eyes? Options: A. Laser Blended Vision, B. Monovision, C. Presbyopia correction, D. Refractive lens exchange Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.

Although this question does not address the safety of LASIK, it is related to the topic of LASIK and provides some context about the procedure.
